options.B: (2) whom is standing on the road,

questions.explanation: "That has" should be "that have" because "philosophers" is plural.

questions.question: This is the girl, (1) who they declared (2) a thief. (3)
questions.explanation: "Who" is incorrect here. It should be "whom" because it is the object of "declared."

questions.question: My father does not like (1) me going to pictures (2) every day. (3)
questions.explanation: "Me going" should be "my going" because a possessive pronoun is required before a gerund (going).

questions.question: She was more beautiful (1) than either of her (2) three sisters. (3)
questions.explanation: "Either" is incorrect because it refers to two things, but "three sisters" is plural. "Any" should be used instead of "either."

questions.question: Let I go.
questions.explanation: The correct sentence is 'Let me go.' The pronoun 'me' should be used after 'let' instead of 'I'.

questions.question: Between you and I, I am taller.
questions.explanation: The correct sentence is 'Between you and me, I am taller.' The pronoun 'me' should be used instead of 'I' because it is the object of the preposition 'between'.

questions.question: Lata sings better than me.
questions.explanation: The correct sentence is 'Lata sings better than I.' The full form would be 'Lata sings better than I do,' and 'I' is the subject.

questions.question: One of the boys have a bicycle.

options.A: One of the boys have a bicycle.
options.B: One of the boys has a bicycle.
options.C: One among the boys have a bicycle.
options.D: One of boys has a bicycle.

questions.explanation: The correct sentence is 'One of the boys has a bicycle.' The verb should be 'has' instead of 'have' because 'one' is singular.

questions.question: Many of the boys has bicycle.

options.A: Many of the boys has bicycle.
options.B: Many of the boys have bicycles.
options.D: Many of the boys had bicycle.

questions.question: (1) Neither of these three candidates (2) is fit for the post.
questions.explanation: 'Neither' is used for two options, not three. The correct sentence is 'None of these three candidates is fit for the post.'

questions.question: (1) Both did not (2) go.
questions.explanation: 'Both did not' is incorrect. The correct sentence is 'Neither of them went' because 'both' is affirmative, and negation should be handled differently.

questions.question: (1) You and he (2) should not waste (3) his money.
questions.explanation: 'His money' is incorrect. It should be 'your money' or 'their money' to correctly refer to both individuals.

questions.question: (1) I who is (2) your father (3) should be respected.
questions.explanation: 'I who is' is incorrect. The correct sentence is 'I who am your father should be respected.' Since 'I' is the subject, the verb should be 'am' instead of 'is'.

questions.question: (1) He is (2) a friend of me.
questions.explanation: 'A friend of me' is incorrect. The correct sentence is 'He is a friend of mine.' The pronoun should be in the possessive form.

questions.question: (1) I hate him (2) talking too much.
questions.explanation: 'Him' should be 'his' because a possessive pronoun is required before a gerund (talking). The correct sentence is 'I hate his talking too much.'

questions.question: (1) None of we (2) accepted his invitation.
questions.explanation: 'None of we' is incorrect. It should be 'None of us' because 'none' takes an objective case pronoun.

questions.question: (1) Who (2) are you referring to?
questions.explanation: 'Who' should be 'whom' because it is the object of the preposition 'to'. The correct sentence is 'Whom are you referring to?'.

questions.question: (1) The jury (2) was divided (3) on this issue.
questions.explanation: No error. 'Jury' is a collective noun, and when divided in opinion, it is treated as plural, but 'was divided' correctly conveys the meaning.

questions.question: (1) Every of the boys (2) has taken (3) his share.
questions.explanation: 'Every of the boys' is incorrect. The correct phrase should be 'Every boy' or 'Each of the boys'.

questions.question: (1) One ought to do (2) his duty.
questions.explanation: 'His' should be 'one's' because 'one' is an indefinite pronoun and must be followed by 'one's' to maintain consistency.

questions.question: (1) He and me (2) went to get (3) the seats reserved.
questions.explanation: 'Me' should be 'I' because it is the subject of the sentence. The correct phrase is 'He and I went to get the seats reserved.'

questions.question: (1) 10 Kms (2) are a long distance.
questions.explanation: 'Are' should be 'is' because distance is considered singular. The correct sentence is '10 Kms is a long distance.'
